text: After another mass shooting over the weekend,

President Biden is again working to 
rally support for new gun restrictions.

And jury deliberations began today in a civil 
case against former President Donald Trump.

Good morning, I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

Texas authorities are gathering more 
information about the gunman in last

weekend's mass shooting in Allen, near 
Dallas. Eight people were killed and

at least seven others were injured. 
Investigators say the gunman who was

shot and killed at the scene appears to have 
held far-right beliefs. He was also wearing

a patch with initials that apparently 
stand for "Right-Wing Death Squad."

Following the Texas mass shooting, NPR's 
Giles Snyder reports President Biden is
seeking to rally support for new gun restrictions:

"At a Monday Night reception at the White House, 
President Biden addressed gun safety again,

calling for a new ban on assault weapons and 
high-capacity magazines. He also wants to end

immunity for gun manufacturers. 
Senate Majority Leader Chuck

Schumer is planning to convene a special 
Democratic caucus meeting on gun safety,

but Democrats have been unable to secure enough 
support to overcome Republican opposition."
NPR's Gile Snyder reporting.

Officials in Brownsville, Texas, have 
filed manslaughter charges against a

man who drove into a group of people 
on Sunday. He killed eight migrants.

A jury in New York is about to start 
deliberating the civil case of sexual

battery and defamation against former 
President Donald Trump. NPR's Andrea

Bernstein reports the case is being 
brought by writer E. Jean Carroll:

"In closing arguments Monday, Carroll's 
attorney said finding Donald Trump not

liable would mean believing 11 witnesses lied 
on the stand and that Donald Trump lied, too,

when he said in the Access Hollywood tape he 
liked to grab women by the genitals because,

'When you're a star, they let you do it.' But 
Trump's lawyers say the assault never happened and

was concocted by Carroll and others to hurt Trump 
politically. After instructions this morning,

the jury will decide, based on the preponderance 
of the evidence, if Trump is liable. If so,

damages could run well into the millions. 
Andrea Bernstein, NPR News, New York."

The Israeli military says it killed three 
Palestinian militant commanders in Gaza today,

leading both Israelis and Palestinians to 
brace for an outburst of violence. Aaron

Boxerman reports from Jerusalem that 
Palestinian health officials say at
least 13 Palestinians were killed in the strikes:

"Israeli fighter jets bombarded the blockaded Gaza 
Strip before dawn on Tuesday, killing three senior

members of Islamic Jihad, a U.S.-designated 
terrorist group. It says the victims include

the commanders' wives and some of their children. 
Israel and Gaza militants have frequently clashed,

most recently last week after an Islamic 
Jihad member died following a three-month

hunger strike in an Israeli jail. This time, both 
sides appear to expect a wider escalation. Gaza

authorities shuttered schools and Israel closed 
checkpoints and roads leading to the enclave.

An Israeli military spokesperson said Israel 
had achieved its goals for now, but that it was

unclear how the situation would develop. For 
NPR News, I'm Aaron Boxerman, in Jerusalem."
This is NPR.
